title: After the Prophet: Chaos, Conflict, and Schism

content.text: The traditional Islamic narrative portrays Muhammad as the perfect leader who established a divinely guided, unified community destined for greatness. But the immediate aftermath of his death in 632 CE tells a starkly different story – one of shock, confusion, denial, backroom political dealing, and the immediate planting of seeds for schisms that would tear the Muslim world apart for centuries. Far from leaving behind a stable, well-prepared community with a clear plan, Muhammad's demise revealed the inherently fragile and personality-driven nature of the power structure he had built.

The news itself sent shockwaves. Many followers, utterly dependent on Muhammad's charismatic leadership, couldn't fathom his mortality. The powerful Umar ibn Al-Khattab famously stood up and denied the Prophet was dead, threatening anyone who claimed otherwise, comparing Muhammad's absence to Moses going up the mountain. It took the level-headed Abu Bakr, quoting the Quran ("Muhammad is no more than a messenger: many were the messengers that passed away before him..."), to bring people back to reality. This initial reaction highlights the intense personality cult surrounding Muhammad – his followers seemed unprepared for a future without his direct guidance.
The Succession Crisis: Sunni vs. Shia Origins

Did Muhammad leave clear instructions for what came next? Sunni tradition largely insists he did not explicitly name a successor, believing the matter should be left to community consultation (shura). Shia tradition vehemently disagrees, citing events like Ghadir Khumm where they believe Muhammad clearly designated his cousin and son-in-law, Ali ibn Abi Talib, as his heir. Regardless of which narrative one accepts, the reality on the ground was immediate political chaos.

While Ali and Muhammad's closest family members (the Ahl al-Bayt) were occupied with the solemn duty of washing and preparing the Prophet's body for burial, a hasty, exclusive meeting was convened by the Medinan Ansar at the meeting place (Saqifa) of the Banu Sa'ida clan. They felt, understandably perhaps, that having supported Muhammad from the beginning, the leadership should now fall to them, potentially even proposing a joint leadership model.

News of this Ansar meeting reached Abu Bakr and Umar, who, fearing a political coup that would exclude the Meccan Muhajirun (especially the Quraysh), rushed to the Saqifa. What followed was a heated political debate, not a calm consultation among all believers. Abu Bakr argued forcefully for Qurayshi leadership, claiming only Muhammad's tribe could command universal respect. In a decisive, arguably preemptive move, Umar seized Abu Bakr's hand and pledged allegiance (bay'ah), quickly followed by others present. Ali, the Prophet's family, and many key companions were completely absent, facing a fait accompli.

This "Saqifa Affair," conducted in haste and excluding crucial stakeholders, established the precedent for caliphal succession but immediately created deep fissures. Ali and his supporters felt cheated, viewing Abu Bakr's selection as illegitimate. While Sunni accounts say Ali eventually gave allegiance (perhaps months later, after Fatima's death), Shia accounts maintain he never truly accepted Abu Bakr's legitimacy.

The immediate aftermath wasn't unity; it was the eruption of the Ridda Wars (Wars of Apostasy), where tribes across Arabia challenged Abu Bakr's authority, some renouncing Islam, others following new "prophets" who sprang up after Muhammad's death. Abu Bakr's short caliphate was largely consumed with brutally suppressing these rebellions.
